pregunta: 1. What measures should be used to prevent tick bites and tick-borne infections according to the clinical practice guidelines?
respuesta:
According to the Clinical Practice Guidelines by the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA), American Academy of Neurology (AAN), and American College of Rheumatology (ACR), the following measures should be used to prevent tick bites and tick-borne infections:

1. Personal protective measures: Individuals at risk of exposure should implement personal protective measures to reduce the risk of tick exposure and infection with tick-borne pathogens.
2. Repellents to prevent tick bites: For prevention of tick bites, recommend using N, N-Diethyl-meta-toluamide (DEET), picaridin, ethyl-3-(Nn-butyl-N-acetyl) aminopropionate (IR3535), oil of lemon eucalyptus (OLE), p-methane-3,8-diol (PMD), 2-undecanone, or permethrin.
3. Removal of attached ticks: It is recommended to promptly remove attached ticks by mechanical means using a clean fine-tipped tweezer or a comparable device inserted between the tick body and the skin.

If you need more detailed information or guidance, it is advisable to refer to the full guideline available at http://online library.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/art.41562/abstract for comprehensive recommendations regarding tick bite prevention and management.

pregunta: 10. For which neurologic presentations should patients be tested for Lyme disease as recommended in the clinical practice guidelines?
respuesta: According to the clinical practice guidelines, patients should be tested for Lyme disease if they present with one or more of the following acute disorders: meningitis, painful radiculoneuritis, mononeuropathy multiplex including confluent mononeuropathy multiplex, acute cranial neuropathies (particularly VII, VIII, less commonly III, V, VI, and others), or if there is evidence of spinal cord (or rarely brain) inflammation, particularly in association with painful radiculitis involving related spinal cord segments, and with epidemiologically plausible exposure to ticks infected with B. burgdorferi. This recommendation is based on strong evidence and moderate-quality evidence.
